target_text: "It is difficult to define and measure. That’s for sure. I think before agile, there was a great focus on product level quality. Mainly free of defects and meets customer’s needs. I saw in agile a shift toward code quality and a design that responds to change. There is also a continuous improvement of the process effort."

Role.Subject: Anthropology
Role.positionality: As a software developer pursuing a Master's in Anthropology with a focus on Economics, my background shapes my research goals to explore the intersection of technology and societal structures. I aim to understand how economic systems influence cultural practices and vice versa. However, I recognize my biases stemming from ethical and societal assumptions inherent in my technical background, which may color my interpretations of anthropological data. This positionality compels me to critically examine how my experiences and perspectives influence my analysis, ensuring that I remain aware of the complexities within the subjects I study and strive for a more nuanced understanding of the human experience.

codebook.justification: The text highlights the inherent difficulties in defining and measuring quality, indicating a subjective interpretation of quality metrics.
The phrase 'shift toward code quality' suggests a transition in priorities, emphasizing the evolving nature of quality assessment in agile methodologies.
The mention of 'continuous improvement of the process effort' reflects an ongoing commitment to enhancing practices, which is a subjective evaluation of progress.
